items.title: Japan's hardline conservative Sanae Takaichi elected first female prime minister

items.title: Japan Set to Have First Female Finance Minister, Reports Say
Sanae Takaichi on course to become Japan’s first female PM after new coalition deal
items.standfirst: Officials confirm reports that Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party will join forces with rightwing Nippon IshinSanae Takaichi is on course to become Japan’s first female prime minister this week after her party agreed to form a new coalition with a minor party.Officials confirmed on Monday that Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party (LDP) had joined forces with the rightwing Nippon Ishin (Japan Innovation party), which shares her hawkish stance on China and support for restrictions on immigration. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials confirm reports that Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party will join forces with rightwing Nippon IshinSanae Takaichi is on course to become Japan’s first female prime minister this week after her party agreed to form a new coalition with a minor party.Officials confirmed on Monday that Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party (LDP) had joined forces with the rightwing Nippon Ishin (Japan Innovation party), which shares her hawkish stance on China and support for restrictions on immigration. Continue reading...

More than 1,000 apps and websites - including social media platforms…

items.title: AWS outage spotlights the global economy's fragile foundations
items.standfirst: Amazon Web Services, the biggest cloud computing provider, went down Monday morning — crippling thousands of services from some of the biggest companies on earth. Why it matters: For all its complexity and size, the global economy is fragile — breaking just one weak link drives big disruptions,…

items.title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?

items.content: Amazon Web Services, a cloud platform that supports a portion of the internet, experienced a massive outage on Monday.

items.title: Outage at Amazon Web Services disrupts websites across the internet
items.standfirst: Amazon's cloud computing service provides back-end support to many companies that operate online. When it has problems, so do they.
items.content: Amazon's cloud computing service provides back-end support to many companies that operate online. When it has problems, so do they.(Image credit: Noah Berger)

items.title: Amazon Web Services outage shows internet users ‘at mercy’ of too few providers, experts say
items.standfirst: Crash that hit apps and websites around world demonstrates ‘urgent need for diversification in cloud computing’Experts have warned of the perils of relying on a small number of companies for operating the global internet after a glitch at Amazon’s cloud computing service brought down apps and websites around the world.The affected platforms included Snapchat, Roblox, Signal and Duolingo as well as a host of Amazon-owned operations including its main retail site and the Ring doorbell company. Continue reading...
items.content: Crash that hit apps and websites around world demonstrates ‘urgent need for diversification in cloud computing’Experts have warned of the perils of relying on a small number of companies for operating the global internet after a glitch at Amazon’s cloud computing service brought down apps and websites around the world.The affected platforms included Snapchat, Roblox, Signal and Duolingo as well as a host of Amazon-owned operations including its main retail site and the Ring doorbell company. Continue reading...

items.title: What the Huge AWS Outage Reveals About the Internet
items.standfirst: Amazon Web Services experienced DNS resolution issues on Monday morning, taking down wide swaths of the web—and highlighting a long-standing weakness in the internet's infrastructure.
items.content: Amazon Web Services experienced DNS resolution issues on Monday morning, taking down wide swaths of the web—and highlighting a long-standing weakness in the internet's infrastructure.

items.title: Amazon Says All Cloud Services Restored After 15-Hour Outage
items.standfirst: Amazon Web Services, the world’s largest cloud provider, resolved the issues that plagued its services for about 15 hours on Monday, an episode that highlighted how much of the internet is dependent on the operations of a single company.
items.content: Amazon Web Services, the world’s largest cloud provider, resolved the issues that plagued its services for about 15 hours on Monday, an episode that highlighted how much of the internet is dependent on the operations of a single company.

ai_summary: Amazon Web Services resolved a major outage affecting numerous websites.
The outage impacted over 1,000 apps and websites, including social media.
The biggest cloud computing provider's outage disrupted many services.
Experts say the outage highlights the fragility of the global economy.
Amazon's cloud services have returned to normal operations after the outage.

items.content: The Toronto Blue Jays reach their first World Series since 1993, beating the Seattle Mariners in the deciding game seven of the American League Championship Series.

items.title: The Dodgers want to win another World Series. The Toronto Blue Jays are in their way

items.content: The Los Angeles Dodgers have put all the chips in on their pursuit of being baseball's first back-to-back champions since 2000. The Blue Jays and their red-hot lineup won't go down easy.(Image credit: Mark Blinch)

items.title: Daniel Naroditsky, American chess grandmaster, dies at 29
items.standfirst: Daniel Naroditsky, a chess grandmaster who started as a child prodigy​ and quickly became one of the most influential American voices in the sport, has died at 29. His cause of death wasn't immediately known.

items.title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom

items.content: Crews tore down a massive covered entryway and windows in the East Wing to make way for Trump's new event space.

items.title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom
items.standfirst: Dramatic photos show construction equipment tearing into the East Wing façade and windows, though the federal agency that oversees such projects has not approved President Trump's 90,000-square-foot, $250 million ballroom.
items.content: Dramatic photos show construction equipment tearing into the East Wing façade and windows, though the federal agency that oversees such projects has not approved President Trump's 90,000-square-foot, $250 million ballroom.(Image credit: Evan Vucci)

items.title: White House begins demolishing part of East Wing for Trump's ballroom
items.standfirst: The White House began demolishing part of its East Wing on Monday to build President Donald Trump’s new ballroom, despite lacking approval from the federal agency that normally oversees such projects. Photos showed a backhoe tearing into the façade as reporters watched from a nearby park near the Treasury Department.
items.content: The White House began demolishing part of its East Wing on Monday to build President Donald Trump’s new ballroom, despite lacking approval from the federal agency that normally oversees such projects. Photos showed a backhoe tearing into the façade as reporters watched from a nearby park near the Treasury Department.

items.title: White House begins demolition of part of East Wing for Trump's ballroom
items.standfirst: President Trump previously said his ballroom addition to the White House wouldn't "interfere" with the building's existing structure.
items.content: President Trump previously said his ballroom addition to the White House wouldn't "interfere" with the building's existing structure.

ai_summary: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing.
The demolition is for President Trump's new ballroom project.
The project lacks approval from the federal agency overseeing projects.
Construction equipment was seen tearing into the East Wing façade.
Trump said the ballroom addition would not interfere with the building.

clusters.title: UK borrowing reaches five-year high for September at £20.2bn
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Government Borrowing Reaches Five-Year High

items.title: UK borrowing reaches five-year high for September at £20.2bn
items.standfirst: Rising debt interest and welfare costs push public finances deeper into red before Rachel Reeves’s budgetBusiness live – lates updatesGovernment borrowing was the highest for five years in September after rising debt interest costs and higher welfare payments pushed the public finances deeper into the red.Figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed public sector net borrowing – the difference between public spending and income – hit £20.2bn last month, up £1.6bn from the same month last year and the highest September borrowing since 2020. Continue reading...
items.content: Rising debt interest and welfare costs push public finances deeper into red before Rachel Reeves’s budgetBusiness live – lates updatesGovernment borrowing was the highest for five years in September after rising debt interest costs and higher welfare payments pushed the public finances deeper into the red.Figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed public sector net borrowing – the difference between public spending and income – hit £20.2bn last month, up £1.6bn from the same month last year and the highest September borrowing since 2020. Continue reading...

items.title: Highest government borrowing in September for five years

items.title: UK lawmakers urge govt to strip Prince Andrew of his titles ahead of Virginia Giuffre's memoir
items.standfirst: UK lawmakers stepped up calls Monday for the government to formally strip Prince Andrew of his titles, as the royal family braced for even more damaging revelations in his accuser Virginia Giuffre's upcoming posthumous memoir. FRANCE 24's correspondent Bénédicte Paviot reports from London.

items.title: UK peace force for Ukraine would cost ‘well over £100m’, says defence secretary
items.standfirst: John Healey says he has already brought forward millions in spending for swift deployment if ceasefire agreedThe cost of Britain’s contribution to a post-ceasefire stabilisation force for Ukraine would be “well over £100m”, the defence secretary, John Healey, has said after a speech in the City of London.Healey said he had already brought forward millions in spending so that a “multinational force Ukraine” led by the UK and France could be ready to deploy quickly if peace talks produce a ceasefire. Continue reading...

items.title: Two killed after cargo plane slides off runway at Hong Kong’s airport
items.standfirst: An investigation is underway in Hong Kong after a cargo plane hit a security vehicle before skidding off the runway into the sea. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports on the deadly incident.
items.content: An investigation is underway in Hong Kong after a cargo plane hit a security vehicle before skidding off the runway into the sea. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports on the deadly incident.

items.content: The Emirates cargo flight hit a vehicle on the ground after it landed at the international airport.

items.title: Two ground staff killed at Hong Kong airport after cargo plane and vehicle go into the sea
items.standfirst: Two people were killed Monday when a cargo plane skidded off a runway at Hong Kong International Airport after it struck a ground service vehicle, sending both the plane and the vehicle into the sea, officials said.
items.content: Two people were killed Monday when a cargo plane skidded off a runway at Hong Kong International Airport after it struck a ground service vehicle, sending both the plane and the vehicle into the sea, officials said.

clusters.title: Inquiry recommends Lisbon funicular trams stay closed after September crash
clusters.neutral_headline: Lisbon Funicular Crash Caused by Faulty Cable

items.title: Inquiry recommends Lisbon funicular trams stay closed after September crash
items.standfirst: September Lisbon funicular crash killed 16 due to faulty cable, prompting closure of other funiculars for safety checks.
items.content: September Lisbon funicular crash killed 16 due to faulty cable, prompting closure of other funiculars for safety checks.

items.title: Faulty cable caused Lisbon funicular crash, inquiry finds
items.standfirst: Report says snapped cable between cabins was substandard and city’s other funiculars should fix risk before reopeningThe funicular that crashed in Lisbon killing 16 people in early September had a faulty cable, the official inquiry said on Monday as it recommended the city’s vehicles stay out of service until their safety can be confirmed.The accident, which saw the picture-postcard 19th-century Elevador da Glória hurtle into a building after careering off the rails, shocked the Portuguese capital and laid bare fears over the safety of the popular yet ageing tourist attraction. Continue reading...
items.content: Report says snapped cable between cabins was substandard and city’s other funiculars should fix risk before reopeningThe funicular that crashed in Lisbon killing 16 people in early September had a faulty cable, the official inquiry said on Monday as it recommended the city’s vehicles stay out of service until their safety can be confirmed.The accident, which saw the picture-postcard 19th-century Elevador da Glória hurtle into a building after careering off the rails, shocked the Portuguese capital and laid bare fears over the safety of the popular yet ageing tourist attraction. Continue reading...

items.title: Crashed Lisbon funicular had faulty cable, official inquiry finds
items.standfirst: The Lisbon funicular that crashed in September killing 16 people and leaving 21 more injured had a faulty cable, an official inquiry found Monday. The report recommends that the city's other funiculars remain out-of-service until investigators can confirm that they're safe for passengers.
items.content: The Lisbon funicular that crashed in September killing 16 people and leaving 21 more injured had a faulty cable, an official inquiry found Monday. The report recommends that the city's other funiculars remain out-of-service until investigators can confirm that they're safe for passengers.

ai_summary: An inquiry found a faulty cable caused the Lisbon funicular crash.
The crash in September killed 16 people and injured 21.
The inquiry recommends other funiculars remain out of service.
The cable between cabins was substandard, according to the report.
The accident raised safety concerns about the tourist attraction.

items.title: Bolivia’s new pro-business leader vows to renew US ties after two decades
items.standfirst: Bolivia’s president-elect Rodrigo Paz vowed Monday to restore diplomatic ties with Washington, signaling a pro-business shift after nearly 20 years of socialist rule blamed for deep economic troubles. The 58-year-old economist-turned-senator won Sunday’s run-off, defeating a right-wing rival after the socialist MAS party was barred following the August vote.
items.content: Bolivia’s president-elect Rodrigo Paz vowed Monday to restore diplomatic ties with Washington, signaling a pro-business shift after nearly 20 years of socialist rule blamed for deep economic troubles. The 58-year-old economist-turned-senator won Sunday’s run-off, defeating a right-wing rival after the socialist MAS party was barred following the August vote.

items.title: Rodrigo Paz Pereira wins Bolivia’s presidential runoff marking a new shift to the right
items.standfirst: Sunday’s election marked the first time since 2005 that no candidate from Evo Morales’ Mas party was on the ballotCentre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, won Bolivia’s presidential runoff on Sunday and will be the country’s next president, marking a shift to the right after nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas) party.With just over 97% of ballots counted in the electoral court’s “preliminary” tally, Paz Pereira secured 54.6% of the vote, while rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga received 45.4%. Continue reading...
items.content: Sunday’s election marked the first time since 2005 that no candidate from Evo Morales’ Mas party was on the ballotCentre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, won Bolivia’s presidential runoff on Sunday and will be the country’s next president, marking a shift to the right after nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas) party.With just over 97% of ballots counted in the electoral court’s “preliminary” tally, Paz Pereira secured 54.6% of the vote, while rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga received 45.4%. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Rodrigo Paz Pereira won Bolivia's presidential runoff.
The election marks a shift to the right.
Paz Pereira will be the next president.
He defeated a right-wing rival in the election.
The election was the first without Evo Morales' party since 2005.

clusters.title: Tiny eye implant, special glasses help some legally blind patients read again
clusters.neutral_headline: Eye Implant and Glasses Help Blind Patients Read

items.title: Tiny eye implant, special glasses help some legally blind patients read again
items.standfirst: The treatment involves inserting a tiny implant thinner than human hair under the retina. Patients then have to wear glasses that project near-infrared light to the implant.
items.content: The treatment involves inserting a tiny implant thinner than human hair under the retina. Patients then have to wear glasses that project near-infrared light to the implant.

items.title: With a tiny eye implant and special glasses, some legally blind patients can read again
items.standfirst: People with a leading cause of blindness were able to read again thanks to a tiny wireless chip implanted in the back of the eye and specialized augmented glasses, according to study results published Monday in the New England Journal of Medicine.
items.content: People with a leading cause of blindness were able to read again thanks to a tiny wireless chip implanted in the back of the eye and specialized augmented glasses, according to study results published Monday in the New England Journal of Medicine.

ai_summary: A tiny eye implant helps some legally blind patients.
The implant is thinner than a human hair.
Patients wear glasses projecting near-infrared light.
The treatment allows patients to read again.
The implant is placed under the retina.

clusters.title: Nigerian police clashed Monday with protesters demanding the release of Nnamdi Kanu
clusters.neutral_headline: Nigerian Police Clash with Protesters

items.title: Nigerian police clashed Monday with protesters demanding the release of Nnamdi Kanu
items.standfirst: In Lagos tensions have been boiling over as protesters demand the release of the Seperatist leader, Nnamdi Kanu. Police used tear gas on demonstrators while there were also reports of gunshots being fired. Dozens were arrested... Kanu who is the leader of the banned Indigenous People of Biafra group, is currently on trial on terrorism charges... His case has caused tension in southeast Nigeria, where the Igbo ethnic group allege marginalization by the Nigerian government.
items.content: In Lagos tensions have been boiling over as protesters demand the release of the Seperatist leader, Nnamdi Kanu. Police used tear gas on demonstrators while there were also reports of gunshots being fired. Dozens were arrested... Kanu who is the leader of the banned Indigenous People of Biafra group, is currently on trial on terrorism charges... His case has caused tension in southeast Nigeria, where the Igbo ethnic group allege marginalization by the Nigerian government.

items.title: Nigerian police fire tear gas as protesters gather over separatist leader
items.standfirst: The protesters are seeking the release of Nnamdi Kanu who has been in detention since 2021 on terrorism charges.
items.content: The protesters are seeking the release of Nnamdi Kanu who has been in detention since 2021 on terrorism charges.

ai_summary: Nigerian police clashed with protesters in Lagos.
Protesters demanded the release of Nnamdi Kanu.
Police used tear gas on demonstrators.
Kanu is the leader of the banned Indigenous People of Biafra.
He is currently on trial for terrorism charges.
